title: Md Moshi Ul Alam
text:
Email    CV    Scholar    

Hi!üòä I am a labor economist. My research interests are in answering microeconomic questions on economic inequality in Labor and Public Economics. Depending on the question, I use either design-based, or model-based methods, or both. I received my PhD in Economics, from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Starting Fall 2024, I will join Clark University, as an Assistant Professor of Economics.


 Working papers

Employee-Side Discrimination: Beliefs and Preferences (PhD JMP)

with Mehreen Mookerjee and Sanket Roy  [+Abstract] 

R&R at Quantitative Economics


Labor Market Consequences of Pay-Equity Laws (Post-doc JMP)

with Steven Lehrer and Nuno Souso Pereira  [+Abstract] 

Updated draft coming soon!


Female Inheritance Rights and Household Sanitation

with Monica Agarwal  [+Abstract] 

Updated draft coming soon!







 Publications/Accepted

‚ÄúIncreases in shared custody after divorce in the United States.‚Äù

with Daniel Meyer and Marcia Carlson.  [+Abstract]   [ Replication]

Demographic Research 46 (2022): 1137-1162.  ‚ÄúEditor‚Äôs Choice‚Äù article





 Research in progress

Optimal Place-Based Redistribution

with Morris Davis and Jesse Gregory

Spatial Inequality and School Choice Mechanisms

with Monica Agarwal, Chao Fu, YingHua He

Labor Market Inequality and Collective Bargaining

with Steven Lehrer and Nuno Souso Pereira

Racial Gaps in Wage Growth: Discrimination, Selection and Search Frictions






Dormant papers

Identification in Models of Discrimination

[subsumed in my PhD job market paper ‚ÄúEmployee Side Discrimination: Beliefs and Preferences‚Äù]





Code
micro = require("micromodal@0.4.10");

micro.init({
  awaitOpenAnimation: true,
  awaitCloseAnimation: true
});






















Increases in shared custody after divorce in the United States


This paper provides new evidence on the time trend in shared physical custody after divorce in the U.S., using eight waves of data from the Current Population Survey - Child Support Supplement. We find that the likelihood of shared custody more than doubled between divorces that occurred before 1985 and those in 2010-2014, from 12% to 28%. We show that non-Hispanic Whites and those who are more socioeconomically advantaged are more likely to have shared custody. Using more formal methods we show that the increase cannot be explained by changes in the characteristics of those divorcing; instead, we infer that this is the result of changing norms and policies that favor shared custody. Finally, this paper complements previous analyses using court record data from Wisconsin and shows that while the rate of shared custody in Wisconsin is higher than the national rate, a large increase over time has occurred in the nation as well as in Wisconsin. These changing patterns have important implications for children‚Äôs living arrangements and for the parental investments that children receive after their parents‚Äô divorce.

Increases in shared custody after divorce in the United States


This paper provides new evidence on the time trend in shared physical custody after divorce in the U.S., using eight waves of data from the Current Population Survey - Child Support Supplement. We find that the likelihood of shared custody more than doubled between divorces that occurred before 1985 and those in 2010-2014, from 12% to 28%. We show that non-Hispanic Whites and those who are more socioeconomically advantaged are more likely to have shared custody. Using more formal methods we show that the increase cannot be explained by changes in the characteristics of those divorcing; instead, we infer that this is the result of changing norms and policies that favor shared custody. Finally, this paper complements previous analyses using court record data from Wisconsin and shows that while the rate of shared custody in Wisconsin is higher than the national rate, a large increase over time has occurred in the nation as well as in Wisconsin. These changing patterns have important implications for children‚Äôs living arrangements and for the parental investments that children receive after their parents‚Äô divorce.

title: Reproducible julia projects
text: A workflow that starts your project to be reproducible from day one, will reduce your work going forward. Since I have started using this workflow, I have realized that by construction it forces certain good habits. In this post, I will share a simple example of creating a reproducible project in julia, by using julia environments. The setup below will ensure that the correct versions of your dependencies are used automatically on any given machine.

title: Reproducible julia projects
section: Setting up a julia project environment
text:
Setting up a julia project environment
First, setting up a new julia project typically involves creating the working directory, initializing the environment within that directory, and then modifying the environment, e.g.¬†adding any necessary packages.
mkdir -p path/to/MyCoolProject
cd path/to/MyCoolProject
Then I typically create a setup.jl file in the path/to/MyCoolProject/code folder to activate the environment and adding neccesary packages.
using Pkg
cd(@__DIR__)
Pkg.activate(@__DIR__)
These commands will create a Project.toml and Manifest.toml file in your project directory. These files will track your project dependencies and their exact versions, ensuring reproducibility.

Once you‚Äôve initialized your project, you can add packages to it, as you normally would.
# Add packages to your project
(MyCoolProject) pkg> add DataFrames
Adding the very first package does two things: 1. Updates Project.toml: It adds DataFrames to the list of dependencies. 2. Updates Manifest.toml: It records the exact version of DataFrames and its dependencies to ensure reproducibility.

title: Reproducible julia projects
text:
Reusing and modifying your environment
If you‚Äôve closed your julia session and want to continue working on your project later, navigate back to your project directory and reactivate the environment:
cd("path/to/MyCoolProject")
julia> ]
(v1.9) pkg> activate .
This reactivates the environment associated with the Project.toml and Manifest.toml files in the same directory.
To add more packages to your project at any time:
(MyCoolProject) pkg> add Plots
This command updates your environment to include the Plots package. The Project.toml and Manifest.toml files will be updated accordingly.
To see the current status of your environment:
(MyCoolProject) pkg> update

title: Reproducible julia projects
text:
Sharing your environment
To share your project with others, provide the directory containing Project.toml and Manifest.toml. Others can recreate your environment by running:
julia> ]
(v1.9) pkg> activate .
(MyCoolProject) pkg> instantiate
The instantiate command installs all the dependencies listed in Manifest.toml, recreating your exact environment.
Setting Up the Project on a Different Machine: - When you clone a project repository or copy a project folder to a different machine, the Manifest.toml file contains the exact versions of all dependencies needed. - Running Pkg.instantiate in this context installs these exact versions, recreating the original environment.
julia> ]
(v1.9) pkg> instantiate
The instantiate command has two more useful features:

Restoring an Environment:

If you‚Äôve made changes to your environment or accidentally removed packages and want to restore the environment to the exact state described in the Manifest.toml, you can use Pkg.instantiate to reinstall all necessary dependencies.
This is also useful if you‚Äôve deleted the ~/.julia/environments directory or are switching between environments and want to ensure the current project has all the required packages.

Ensuring consistency across users: If you‚Äôre working in a shared project and the Manifest.toml has been updated by someone else (e.g., new packages have been added or versions changed), running Pkg.instantiate will synchronize your local environment with the latest dependencies as defined in the Manifest.toml.

In a separate post I will cover my basic setup to version control my scriptss using git and hosting them on GitHub.

title: Podcasts
text:
Podcasts can at times offer an engaging and accessible way to grasp the underlying intuition of various econometric methods. They aid in building a deeper understanding of these methods and in exploring a wide range of problems through the lens of economics.
I found the following episodes to be particularly interesting. This is a continously evolving list. Suggestions are welcome!

RCT:

Amy Finkelstein on the impact of health insurance (Oregon Medicaid expansion) experiment. ‚ÄúHow do we know what really works in healthcare?‚Äù ‚Äì Freakonomics (April 2, 2015)
Nicholas Bloom on the impact of working from home on productivity. ‚ÄúWhen you start to miss Tony from Accounting‚Äù ‚Äì Hidden Brain (Nov 2020)
Jim Heckman on the impact of early childhood investments on long run outcomes. ‚ÄúWhats not on the test‚Äù ‚Äì Hidden Brain
John List (U-Chicago) on the rise of RCT and worries of scaling up experiments (SUTVA violations). ‚ÄúThe Price of Doing Business with John List‚Äù ‚Äì People I (Mostly) Admire
‚ÄúA Nobel-Prize for Development RCTs!‚Äù by David McKenzie World Bank Blog



IV (Continuous and discrete treatments):

Sairt Weisburd on Police presence and Crime ‚Äì Probable Causation July 21, 2020
Carolina Artega on Parental Incarceration and Educational outcomes ‚Äì Probable Causation July 20, 2021



D-i-D:

Molly Schnell on how exposure to school shootings affects students‚Äô outcomes Probable Causation March 15, 2022
(advanced) Adrew Goodman-Bacon on recent advances on D-i-D with staggered timing APPAM - Methodological Advances for Difference-in-Differences with Staggered Timing



RD:

‚ÄúIf Mayors ruled the worlds‚Äù Freakonomics April 10, 2014
‚ÄúWhy is Uber an Economist‚Äôs Dream?‚Äù Freakonomics September 7, 2016
Michael Lovenheim on grade retention and crime. Probable Causation September 17, 2019
Gaurav Khanna on Employment and Crime in Colombia. Probable Causation Aug 17, 2021



Diff-in-RD (advanced)

Kirabo Jackson on single-sex education and academic and criminal outcomes. Probable Causation March 31, 2020

title: Structural and reduced form methods in labor economics: Course Outline
text:
Outline

Principles of empirical research

Identification

‚ÄúNon-parametric identification‚Äù, Matzkin (2007)
‚ÄúIdentification of models of the labor market‚Äù Taber and French (2010)

Advantages of reduced form methods and advantages of structural models
Feasibility of each approach individually and jointly
‚ÄúStructural Equations, Treatment Effects and Econometric Policy Evaluation‚Äù Heckman and Vytlacil (2003)

Reduced form methods

Shift-share exclusion restrictions

‚ÄúBartik Instruments: What, When, Why and How‚Äù Goldsmith-Pinkham, Sorkin and Swift (2020)
‚ÄúQuasi-experimental shift-share research designs‚Äù Borusyak, Hull and Jaravel (2020)

Variation in treatment timings and heterogenous effects

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs trending in difference-in-differences?‚Äù Roth and Santa‚ÄôAnna (2022)
‚ÄúTwo-way fixed effects estimators with heterogeneous treatment effects‚Äù de Chaisemartin and d`Haultfoeuille (2020)
‚ÄúInheritance rights and household sanitation‚Äù Alam and Agarwal (2023)

Empirical Bayes

‚ÄúEmpirical Bayes deconvolution estimates.‚Äù Efron (2016)
‚ÄúSystemic discrimination among large US employers‚Äù, Kline, Rose and Walters (2022)
‚ÄúRobust empirical bayes confidence intervals‚Äù Armstrong, Koles√°r and Plagborg-M√∏ller (2022)

Discontinuity based designs

‚ÄúInference on causal effects in a generalized regression kink design‚Äù Card et al.¬†(2015)
‚ÄúInference in Regression Discontinuity Designs with a Discrete Running Variable‚Äù, Kolesar and Rothe (2018)


Structural models

Conditional choice probabilities, discrete choice and dynamic models

‚ÄúConditional Choice Probabilities and the Estimation of Dynamic Models‚Äù, Hotz and Miller (1993)
‚ÄúCollege Attrition and the Dynamics of Information Revelation‚Äù, Arcidiacono, Aucejo, Maurel, et al.¬†(2018)
‚ÄúDiscrete Choice Methods with Simulation‚Äù Train (2009)
‚ÄúThe Structural Estimation of Behavioral Models: Discrete Choice Dynamic Programming Methods and Applications,‚Äù Keane and Wolpin (2011)

Stated preference

‚ÄúPreference for the workplace, investment in human capital and gender‚Äù, Wiswall Zafar (2018)
‚ÄúOptimal Place-based redistribution‚Äù Alam, Davis and Gregory (2023)

‚ÄúUnderstanding Migration Aversion Using Elicited Choice Probabilities‚Äù, Kosar, Ransom, van der Klaauw (2022)

Models on wage inequality

‚ÄúHigh wage workers and high wage firms‚Äù Abowd, Kramarz and Margolis (1999)
‚ÄúA Distributional Framework for Matched Employer-employee data‚Äù, Bonhomme, Lamadon, Manresa (2019)
‚ÄúRacial Gaps in Wage Growth: Discrimination and Search Frictions‚Äù Alam (2020)
‚ÄúDiscretizing Unobserved heterogeneity‚Äù Bonhomme, Lamadon, Manresa (2019)
‚ÄúMonopsony in Movers: The Elasticity of Labor Supply to Firm Wage Policies‚Äù, Bassier, Dube, Naidu (2021)


Using both reduced form and structural models

‚ÄúWorker-side discrimination‚ÄìBeliefs and Preferences - Evidence from an Information Experiment on Jobseekers‚Äù, Alam, Mookerjee, Roy (2022)
‚ÄúEstimating Equilibrium Effects of Job Search Assistance,‚Äù Gautier, Muller, van der Klaauw, Rosholm and Svarer (2018)
‚ÄúThe Demand for Food of Poor Urban Mexican Households: Understanding Policy Impacts Using Structural Models‚Äù Angelucci and Attanasio (2013)
‚ÄúEvaluating Search and Matching Models Using Experimental Data‚Äù Lise, Seitz and Smith (2015)
‚ÄúEvaluating a Structural Model of Labor Supply and Welfare Participation: Evidence from State Welfare Reform Experiments,‚Äù Choi (2018)
‚ÄúEstimating labour supply responses and welfare participation: Using a natural experiment to validate a structural labour supply model‚Äù Hansen and Liu (2015)
‚ÄúThe Role of Labor and Marriage Markets, Preference Heterogeneity and the Welfare System on the Life Cycle Decisions of Black, Hispanic and White Women,‚Äù Keane and Wolpin (2010)
‚ÄúApproximating the Equilibrium Effects of Informed School Choice,‚Äù Allende, Gallego and Nielson (2019)

Coding in Julia (if time permits)

Why Julia?
Efficient code, version control and large project workflow
Automatic testing and reproducibility
Introduction to numerical optimization

title: Resources for undergrad students
text:
Students are free to use any language of their preference‚ÄìStata, R, julia, python, Matlab etc. Historically, most students have used Stata for the analysis they conduct in their term paper.
I strongly encourage students to use open-source languages like R, julia and python.
Besides google search being a very good friend while picking up any language, here are some resources on Stata from the internet that may be useful for students.

Social Science Computing Center at UW-Madison
Data and Statistical services at Princeton
Advanced Research computing at UCLA
Project management in Stata
Transitioning between Stata and R

Most of them, have corresponding pages for R as well.

title: Econ 452: Course Outline
text:
Outline

Potential Outcomes Framework (1 lecture)
Randomized Control Trials (1.5 lectures)
Regressions (1.5 lectures)
Non-linear regressions (2 lectures)
Instrumental Variables (5 lectures)
Heterogeneous Treatment Effects (1 lecture)
Panel data and Fixed Effects (3 lectures)
Difference-in-Differences (5 lectures)
Regression Discontinuity (2 lectures)
Inference (1 lecture)
Take away from the course (1 lecture)



Assessment

10% Discussion and class participation
30% 5 Problem sets
60% Group project

title: Version control
text: Disclaimer: There are many maazing resources all over the internet on how to version control. What I have shared below is the minimal requirement that works for me.

title: Version control
section: Step 1: Initialize Git in Your Project
text:
Step 1: Initialize Git in Your Project
Navigate to your project directory and initialize a Git repository:
cd path/to/MyCoolProject/code
git init
This creates a new Git repository in the MyCoolProject/code directory.

title: Version control
text:
Step 2: Create a .gitignore File in /code
To exclude certain files from being tracked by Git, create a .gitignore file in the /code directory. Suppose you want to ignore all files with extension .bak and the folder called temp.
# Ignore temporary files
*.bak
/temp/
Although you can create multiple .gitignore within subfolders. I typically prefer having a single gitignore in the main directory and then use relative paths to ensure which files and folders I want git to ignore.

title: Version control
section: Step 3: Connect to a Remote Repository (GitHub)
text:
Step 3: Connect to a Remote Repository (GitHub)
I host my version controlled files on GitHub.

Create a new repository on GitHub
Add the remote URL to your local Git repository:

git remote add origin https://github.com/YourUsername/MyCoolProject-code.git

title: Version control
section: Step 4: Stage and Commit Your Files
text:
Step 4: Stage and Commit Your Files






Confirm working branch





Ensure you are on the same branch as your primary branch in your repo. In my first attempt my primary branch in the repo was main while that on VSCode was master. The solution to this is a careful force merge of the two branches:
git checkout main
git merge master --allow-unrelated-histories



After setting up the remote repository, you can stage and commit your files. Itypically do this on the fly using VSCode default GUI.

Click on the Source Control icon in the left sidebar in VSCode.
You should see all your files listed as untracked. Click on the + icon next to each file to stage them, or click + next to Changes to stage all files.
Enter a commit message in the text box at the top.
Click on the checkmark icon to commit your staged changes.
Push your changes to the remote repository.

title: Version control
text:
Step 5: Track Changes and Collaborate
Now that your /code folder is under version control and hosted on GitHub, you can track changes, create branches, merge changes, and collaborate with others. VSCode provides a powerful interface for managing Git repositories, making it easier to review changes and resolve conflicts.
